p: Climate change is expected to impose strong directional selection pressures on plant populations (Davis & Woods, 1986; Davis & Shaw, 2001; Jump & Peñuelas, 2005; Bradshaw & Holzapfel, 2006; Reusch & Wood, 2007; Anderson et al., 2012). In response, plant populations may adapt in situ via selection on standing genetic variation (Hoffmann & Willi, 2008; Jump et al., 2008a). This adaptive response could be an important component of species' resistance to climate change, because it would provide an in situ ‘option’ for persistence in spite of environmental change (Jump et al., 2008a).
